The usual definition of K-derivation on a K-algebra AAA (i.e. a K-linear map D:A→AD:A \to AD:A→A such that D(ab)=D(a)b+aD(b)D(ab)=D(a)b+aD(b)D(ab)=D(a)b+aD(b)) seems to be readily generalizable to K-linear categories, by saying that a derivation D:A→AD:\cal A \to AD:A→A of such categories is given by a function on objects, locally linear maps on morphisms, and instead of functoriality requiring that D(f;g)=D(f);g+f;D(g)D(f;g)=D(f);g + f;D(g)D(f;g)=D(f);g+f;D(g).
Notice this directly generalizes the traditional definition since a K-algebra is a one-object K-linear category.

Has anyone ever heard of these? I didn't finid anything on Google but I'd be suprised if I'm the first to think about these things

You can even define the generalized version of derivations in which the codomain is just an AAA-bimodule: replace AAA-bimodule with 'two-sided fibration over A\cal AA' (of course, a suitably enriched in KModK\bf ModKMod), i.e. a two-sided fibration A←M→A\cal A \leftarrow M \to AA←M→A.

Then replace Leibniz with

D(fg)=f∗Dg+g∗DfD(fg) = f^*Dg + g_*DfD(fg)=f∗Dg+g∗​Df
To have this typecheck, DDD has to be a section of both sides of the two-sided fibration
Alternatively, you can replace two-sided fibration with bifibration, which makes being a section easier
It seems like such a derivation can send isomorphic objects to non-isomorphic objects. Indeed, if D is zero on morphisms, there is no restriction on what it can do to objects. Is this the intention?
Yeah these are not functors so there's no expectation for them to be isomorphism-preserving
Not sure what the map on objects is even getting you here though.

My instinct would be to say "a derivation DDD riding a functor F:A→BF : \mathcal{A} \to \mathcal{B}F:A→B is given by local linear maps Dx,y:A(x,y)→B(F(x),F(y))D_{x,y} : \mathcal{A}(x,y) \to \mathcal{B}(F(x),F(y))Dx,y​:A(x,y)→B(F(x),F(y)) satisfying D(f;g)=F(f);D(g)+D(f);F(g)D(f;g) = F(f);D(g) + D(f);F(g)D(f;g)=F(f);D(g)+D(f);F(g)".

This gives them the structure of a KKK-module. But maybe they should actually have the structure of an A\mathcal{A}A-presheaf or profunctor from A\mathcal{A}A to A\mathcal{A}A or something, and I'm less sure how to define them so that that happens.
This is the kind of thing where it wouldn't hurt to have an application in mind ...

James Deikun said:

This is the kind of thing where it wouldn't hurt to have an application in mind ...

Yeah indeed... I'm trying to understand whether such a notion could help shed light on some constructions in differential categories, chiefly the Faà di Bruno comonad. The point is that one can see the chain rule as saying that taking derivatives is a section of a fibration, for instance a section of the codomain fibration B↓→BB^\downarrow \to BB↓→B (I'm simplyfing). But then when you take higher derivatives, the chain rule has to be combined with the Leibniz rule.
This comes from a subtlety: chain rule in first-year calculus is defined as D(f;g)(x)=D(g)(f(x))⋅f(x)D(f;g)(x) = D(g)(f(x)) \cdot f(x)D(f;g)(x)=D(g)(f(x))⋅f(x), i.e. uses multiplication, but in differential geometry (third-year calculus?) multiplication seems to disappear: d(f;g)(x,v)=dgf(x)(dfx(v))d(f;g)(x,v) = dg_{f(x)}(df_x(v))d(f;g)(x,v)=dgf(x)​(dfx​(v))!

The resolution of the conundrum, of course, is that multiplication in first-year calculus is actually the application of a linear map to a vector, like in third-year calculus. This, however (and here's where I might be mistaken) suggests that the Leibniz rule is about the derivative of applications of linear maps, hence suggesting that it might be captured by an horizontal categorification of the notion of derivation in differential algebra.

I mean I think the map on objects in your definition is losing you structure without getting any useful flexibility in return.
What structure is it losing?
Or better, why do you think adding a functorial action too would improve the situation? :thinking:

Matteo Capucci (he/him) said:

Uhm why a functor? I was moving along the correspondence 'category : two-sided fibration = ring : bimodule'

Besides the notion of a derivation into a bimodule, there's a notion of a derivation riding an algebra homomorphism; this is the higher equivalent of that. I think derivation into a bimodule does subsume it though. But I think introducing this idea clarifies why you don't want the object map; a "plain" derivation should be riding the identity functor.

I think the proper equivalent here of a bimodule derivation is a derivation riding a K-linear profunctor P:A ⇸ AP : \mathcal{A} \: ⇸ \: \mathcal{A}P:A⇸A where Dx,y:A(x,y)→P(x,y)D_{x,y} : \mathcal{A}(x,y) \to P(x,y)Dx,y​:A(x,y)→P(x,y) where D(f;g)=f;D(g)+D(f);gD(f ; g) = f ; D(g) + D(f) ; gD(f;g)=f;D(g)+D(f);g where the ;;; on the right is the action of the profunctor. This subsumes the above definition when P=A(F,F)P = \mathcal{A}(F,F)P=A(F,F).

Matteo Capucci (he/him) said:

What structure is it losing?

It's losing K-linear structure on the space of derivations.

I like derivations taking values in a bimodule of a ring or algebra, and I like @James Deikun's idea of generalizing these to derivations riding V\mathsf{V}V-enriched profunctor P:A→AP: \mathsf{A} \to \mathsf{A}P:A→A, i.e. P:A⊗Aop→VP : \mathsf{A} \otimes \mathsf{A}^{\text{op}} \to \mathsf{V}P:A⊗Aop→V. It looks like we only need V\mathsf{V}V to be CommMon\mathsf{CommMon}CommMon-enriched to make sense of the addition in the formula for a derivation, and also the linearity of the derivation.
But we could take V=AbGp\mathsf{V} = \mathsf{AbGp}V=AbGp or V=Vectk\mathsf{V} = \mathsf{Vect}_kV=Vectk​ for some field kkk if we want things to be more familiar.
I feel I may be making a level slip somewhere, but I hope not.

Ah uhm right, there you need to use two-sided codiscrete cofibrations instead...

I'm more interested in this remark though:
James Deikun said:

It's losing K-linear structure on the space of derivations.

I'm having a tough time seeing how derivations D:A→PD:\mathcal A \to PD:A→P (where PPP is a K-linear profunctor) would form a K-linear category, unless we still make them into an algebra, i.e. a one-object K-linear category. This works but it's a bit weird..?
Well, with this definition the structure that derivations have is just that they live in V\mathsf{V}V (possibly up to size). Which is at least something!
James didn't say derivations formed a category, just that you can add them and multiply them by elements of KKK. And I think that should be true if we define them correctly (in the KKK-linear case).
There might also be a nice structure where composition of endoprofunctors induces a heterogeneous composition on derivations, but I'd have to explicitly work it out to be 100% sure.
(I'm only, like, 60% sure.)

Usually when I think about higher derivations, btw, the cleanest framework seems to be that of Hasse-Schmidt derivations. You can generalize Hasse-Schmidt derivations from their usual context to a bimodule context, with an appropriate notion of power series algebra.

Here we can define the power series category P[[t]]P[[t]]P[[t]] generated by a V\mathsf{V}V-enriched profunctor P:A→AP : \mathsf{A} \to \mathsf{A}P:A→A (where V\mathsf{V}V itself is CommMon\mathsf{CommMon}CommMon-enriched) as a category enriched in N\mathbb{N}N-graded objects of V\mathsf{V}V, where:

  • P[[t]](x,y)n=Pn(x,y)P[[t]](x,y)_n = P^n(x,y)P[[t]](x,y)n​=Pn(x,y) (PnP^nPn is the nnn-fold self-composition of PPP)
  • (f∘g)n=∑k=0nfk∘gn−k(f \circ g)_n = \sum_{k = 0}^n f_k \circ g_{n-k}(f∘g)n​=∑k=0n​fk​∘gn−k​ (∘\circ∘ on the right is the semi-formal composition in Pn−k∘Pk≅PnP^{n-k} \circ P^{k} \cong P^{n}Pn−k∘Pk≅Pn)
Then a Hasse-Schmidt derivation into PPP is just a functor from A\mathsf{A}A to P[[t]]P[[t]]P[[t]]!
The higher-order Leibniz rules fall out of this formalism really naturally; I wonder if something similar can happen with higher-order chain rules.
